languages.text: Словесами своими изваял он пред монахами видение гордых чертогов, в которых восседают оне царями и паствой помыкают единовластно. Многим по нраву пришлось видение сие. Позабыли братия смирение, и взяли грех, и облачились во злато, и власа свои украсили каменьями, и в сердцах уповали уж не на святого Когнация, а на Вольного Торговца. Тех же, кто не знал измены присягам святым, хулили и извергали прочь, и бежали мы в горы, и страдали от хлада и бескормицы. Помилуй нас Бог-Император за робость нашу и грех наш.

With {mf|his|her} words, {mf|he|she} wove before the monks a vision of proud palaces in which they sat as kings and ruled over their flock with power absolute. Many were pleased with this vision. The brethren forgot humility, and took to sin, arraying themselves in gold, and adorning their hair with gems, and in their hearts trusting not in Saint Cognatius, but in the Rogue Trader. Those who did not know treason against the holy vows were dispraised and cast out, and we fled to the mountains, and suffered from cold and want of fodder. May the God-Emperor have mercy on us for our timidity and our sin.
languages.original_text: Словесами своими изваял он пред монахами видение гордых чертогов, в которых восседают оне царями и паствой помыкают единовластно. Многим по нраву пришлось видение сие. languages.text: Con sus palabras formó para los monjes una visión: orgullosos palacios donde vivían como reyes, gobernando con poder absoluto a su rebaño. La visión fue del agrado de muchos de ellos. La hermandad olvidó la humildad y se entregó al pecado, ataviándose con oro y trenzando con gemas su pelo, y confiando sus corazones no a san Cognatius, sino a{mf|l| la} Comerciante Independiente. Quienes no traicionaron sus sagrados juramentos fueron reprochados y expulsados, huyendo a las montañas donde sufrieron el frío y la escasez de alimentos. Que el Dios Emperador se apiade de nuestra timidez y nuestras faltas.
languages.original_text: With {mf|his|her} words, {mf|he|she} wove before the monks a vision of proud palaces in which they sat as kings and ruled over their flock with power absolute. Many were pleased with this vision. The brethren forgot humility, and took to sin, arraying themselves in gold, and adorning their hair with gems, and in their hearts trusting not in Saint Cognatius, but in the Rogue Trader. La hermandad olvidó la humildad y se entregó al pecado, ataviándose con oro y trenzando con gemas su pelo, y confiando sus corazones no a san Cognatius, sino a{mf|l| la} Comerciante Independiente. Que el Dios Emperador se apiade de nuestra timidez y nuestras faltas.

languages.text: 自由開拓者は自身の言葉で、修道士たちを相手に、彼らが王座に就き、絶対的な権力を持って民衆を支配する、誇り高き宮殿の夢物語を語ってみせた。多くの者は、この夢物語を喜んで聞いた。修道士たちは謙虚な心を忘れ、罪を犯し、金を身に纏い、宝石を髪飾りにして、彼らの心は聖コグナティウスではなく、自由開拓者を信じた。聖なる誓いに背く心を持たぬ者たちは責め立てられ、追放された。追放された者たちは山へと逃げ込み、寒さと食糧の不足に苦しんだ。神帝陛下よ、臆病で罪深き我々にどうかお慈悲を。
languages.original_text: With {mf|his|her} words, {mf|he|she} wove before the monks a vision of proud palaces in which they sat as kings and ruled over their flock with power absolute. Many were pleased with this vision. The brethren forgot humility, and took to sin, arraying themselves in gold, and adorning their hair with gems, and in their hearts trusting not in Saint Cognatius, but in the Rogue Trader. Those who did not know treason against the holy vows were dispraised and cast out, and we fled to the mountains, and suffered from cold and want of fodder. May the God-Emperor have mercy on us for our timidity and our sin.

traits.locale_text: 自由開拓者は自身の言葉で、修道士たちを相手に、彼らが王座に就き、絶対的な権力を持って民衆を支配する、誇り高き宮殿の夢物語を語ってみせた。多くの者は、この夢物語を喜んで聞いた。修道士たちは謙虚な心を忘れ、罪を犯し、金を身に纏い、宝石を髪飾りにして、彼らの心は聖セファスではなく、自由開拓者を信じた。聖なる誓いに背く心を持たぬ者たちは責め立てられ、追放された。追放された者たちは山へと逃げ込み、寒さと食糧の不足に苦しんだ。神帝陛下よ、臆病で罪深き我々にどうかお慈悲を。

languages.text: 在{mf|他|她}诱人的话语中，所有僧侣都看到了这样的未来——在高耸入云的宫殿中，僧侣们像国王一样高高在上，以绝对的权力统治着他们的牧群。许多僧侣对这样的愿景非常满意，他们忘记了谦卑，陷入了犯罪的泥淖之中。他们开始披金戴银，将华美的珠宝当做头饰。他们不再坚守圣科尼亚蒂乌斯的教诲，而是对行商浪人马首是瞻。至于那些不肯背弃神圣誓言的人，则遭到了排挤、驱逐。在这样的情况下，我们逃到了寒冷的山间，过着缺衣少食的生活。愿神皇宽恕我们的懦弱和罪恶。
languages.original_text: With {mf|his|her} words, {mf|he|she} wove before the monks a vision of proud palaces in which they sat as kings and ruled over their flock with power absolute. Many were pleased with this vision. The brethren forgot humility, and took to sin, arraying themselves in gold, and adorning their hair with gems, and in their hearts trusting not in Saint Cognatius, but in the Rogue Trader. Those who did not know treason against the holy vows were dispraised and cast out, and we fled to the mountains, and suffered from cold and want of fodder. May the God-Emperor have mercy on us for our timidity and our sin.

traits.locale_text: 在{mf|他|她}诱人的话语中，所有僧侣都看到了这样的未来——在高耸入云的宫殿中，僧侣们像国王一样高高在上，以绝对的权力统治着他们的牧群。许多僧侣对这样的愿景非常满意，他们忘记了谦卑，陷入了犯罪的泥淖之中。他们开始披金戴银，将华美的珠宝当做头饰。他们不再坚守圣科尼亚蒂乌斯的教诲，而是对行商浪人马首是瞻。至于那些不肯背弃神圣誓言的人，则遭到了排挤、驱逐。在这样的情况下，我们逃到了寒冷的山间，过着缺衣少食的生活。愿神皇宽恕我们的懦弱和罪恶。

languages.text: Ses paroles dépeignent de glorieux palais dans lesquels les moines siègent tels des rois et règnent sur leurs ouailles avec un pouvoir absolu. Cette vision ravit nombre des frères, qui se détournent de l'humilité pour embrasser le péché. Ils se vêtissent d'or et parent leurs cheveux de joyaux, tandis que dans leur cœur, {mf|le libre-marchand|la libre-marchande} supplante Saint Cognatius comme objet de leur foi. Ceux qui refusent de trahir les vœux sacrés sont dénigrés et chassés, contraints de se réfugier dans les montagnes où ils souffrent du froid et de la famine. Puisse l'Empereur-Dieu avoir pitié de nous pour notre lâcheté et notre péché.
languages.original_text: With {mf|his|her} words, {mf|he|she} wove before the monks a vision of proud palaces in which they sat as kings and ruled over their flock with power absolute. Many were pleased with this vision. The brethren forgot humility, and took to sin, arraying themselves in gold, and adorning their hair with gems, and in their hearts trusting not in Saint Cognatius, but in the Rogue Trader. Those who did not know treason against the holy vows were dispraised and cast out, and we fled to the mountains, and suffered from cold and want of fodder. May the God-Emperor have mercy on us for our timidity and our sin.

languages.text: Mit {mf|seinen|ihren} Worten wob {mf|er|sie} vor den Mönchen eine Vision von stolzen Palästen, in denen sie als Könige thronten und mit absoluter Macht über ihre Herden herrschten. Viele fanden Gefallen an dieser Vision. Die Brüder vergaßen ihre Bescheidenheit und verfielen der Sünde. Sie hüllten sich in goldene Gewänder und schmückten ihr Haar mit Edelsteinen. Und in ihren Herzen vertrauten sich nicht mehr St. Cognatius, sondern {mf|dem Freihändler|der Freihändlerin}. Jene, die keinen Verrat an den heiligen Eiden begingen, wurden getadelt und verstoßen. Und so flohen wir in die Berge und litten unter der Kälte und dem Mangel an Nahrung. Möge der Gottimperator uns ob unserer Ängstlichkeit und Sünden gnädig sein.
languages.original_text: With {mf|his|her} words, {mf|he|she} wove before the monks a vision of proud palaces in which they sat as kings and ruled over their flock with power absolute. Many were pleased with this vision. The brethren forgot humility, and took to sin, arraying themselves in gold, and adorning their hair with gems, and in their hearts trusting not in Saint Cognatius, but in the Rogue Trader. languages.text: Sözleriyle; keşişlerin krallar gibi oturup sürülerini mutlak güçle yönettikler, gururlu saraylarla dolu görüler aşıladı. Pek çoğu bu manzaradan hoşnut kaldı. Kardeşler, alçak gönüllüğü unutup günah işlemeye başladı. Altınlara büründüler, saçlarını mücevherlerle süslediler ve yüreklerini Aziz Cognatius'a değil de Hür Tacir'e açtılar. Kutsal yeminlerine ihanet etmeyenler, aşağılanıp kovuldu. Biz de dağlara kaçtık, soğuk ve yem sıkıntısı çektik. Tanrı İmparator, çekingenliğimizi ve günahlarımızı affetsin.
languages.original_text: With {mf|his|her} words, {mf|he|she} wove before the monks a vision of proud palaces in which they sat as kings and ruled over their flock with power absolute. Many were pleased with this vision. The brethren forgot humility, and took to sin, arraying themselves in gold, and adorning their hair with gems, and in their hearts trusting not in Saint Cognatius, but in the Rogue Trader. Those who did not know treason against the holy vows were dispraised and cast out, and we fled to the mountains, and suffered from cold and want of fodder. May the God-Emperor have mercy on us for our timidity and our sin.
